comments.commentBody:
@#2 Amos,

Hey, Magic Johnson produced 1 NCAA Championship, 5 NBA Championships and 3 NBA MVP of the year awards. I think Stockton's record is 0-0-0. So I wouldn't exactly say Stockton is "way" more productive than Magic.

discover an undiscovered paradise-yanui beach, south in phuket. Really small and cosy beach with just merely 20-25 people. amazingly clear waters with rock formations for snorkelling. There are 2 sides to yanui. Go up the prompthep cape and come down to the other side of yanui beach. And stay till sunset. a sight unlike any other
Have been visiting the resturant since I can remember.  The food is excellent and great value for money.  Eating at Prakash is on my to do list whenever I am in Bombay
Reeves, health care isn't an entitlement, it's a right.

if you don't take the first step to showing the public what they deserve, you will never get to take the second.  this bill may be very short on what is really needed, a one payer system, but it is a step that i am happy to support.

Perhaps the most ironic part of the entire healthcare debate is the Republicans' insistence that healthcare reform would harm Medicare whilst contending that government involvement in healthcare is inherently bad. I'm surprised Democrats did not more forcefully seize upon this fundamental hypocrisy. The President should have directly asked Republicans what they thought of Medicare at the bipartisan healthcare summit if they are so wary of government involvement.

Congratulations to President Obama, who, in spite of the obstacles, remained true to his commitment.  This reform measure is a major step in preventing the disaster that was certain to eventuate under the existing system.

The fact is, since this was a straight party-line vote, this is what Obama and the Democrats were elected to do. There is a reason the Democrats were able to get so many representatives elected from what had been traditionally Republican areas. They got elected because they promised change, and this is the change they promised. I know clear-thinking doctors who are worried by this bill and I know doctors who think its great. I know people who say that insurance does not equal access and insurance companies that hate it.

Is it as historic and as important as Medicare? No, but it's a start towards universal healthcare. For profit health insurance results in a simple problem of incentives, namely shareholders over policyholders. Anyone who doesn't understand that has not done an objective analysis of the problem. Shareholders suffer when claims are paid. Shareholders suffer if policyholders have chronic conditions. So claims are denied and pre-existing conditions disqualify you from getting a policy. There are very good reasons no other countries have for profit healthcare systems. It doesn't work. Nor does it work here. The US is behind the curve on this.

This bill will fundamentally endanger the social safety net by endangering our nation's economic stability. The current debt, which has been greatly enlarged by the economic bailout and stimulus programs (at a total of around 1.5 trillion dollars), and by interest payments, will now be subject to another massive increase.

There may be a few useful regulations, such as ending pre-existing condition exclusions, but it seems likely the health care bill will enshrine another massive payoff to big business -- in this case the insurance and pharmaceutical industries -- just like the farm bills and highway bills do for those interests. What a scam.

Amazing how everyone here, with the exception or Armey and Nader, were able to transcend their narrow political ideology to affirm a fundamental positive direction and see real progress and real possibility.

I want to know the names of the 34 Democrats who voted against Health Care Reform thereby wishing to deny 32 million Americans health care.   They voted for their own selfish reasons which was not why they were elected......they should be thrown out of office next time they come up for election.

Ralph Nadar is a true American hero. His fight for consumers (particularly single-payer) is a fight for justice and freedom that we should take up. The fight for consumer protections is the single most important pursuit in an America increasingly controlled by thugs masquerading as politicians and CEOs of corporations and banks.

I'm intrigued as to how the Post can call Freedom Works "a national grassroots organization" considering the medical, drug and insurance companies that have been revealed as the sources of its funding.

Rather than operating from consensus, Mr. Armey has strong-armed this group into perpetuating a series of lies about health care reform, actions characterizing demagoguery rather than populism.
Hallelujah!

Did any of these passed without opposition?
- Emancipation Proclamation by Lincoln
- Women's suffrage by Wilson
- Lend/Lease by FDR
- Desegregation of the military by Truman
- Civil Rights Act by Johnson

Who would stand against those today?

Rick Santorum is right. Today is a day of shame for every American, but mainly for Democrats, for allowing Obama and his comrades to force us to swallow a Marxist scam through lies, manipulation, intimidation, coercion, and BRIBES (to be paid by us). In other words, for “winning” following the tactics of Marxists thugs like Hugo Chavez.

Obamacare will destroy our health care, our businesses, jobs, our economy, our freedoms and our country.

Caterpillar said Obamacare would cost them more than 100 million the first year alone! To continue operating in spite of those additional costs, Caterpillar will be forced to fire people and/or take their operations overseas.

Other businesses can anticipate the same problems. And as many companies in the U.S. are barely making it, many will have to close or move to FREER countries.

As a result, millions of people are going to be left not only without insurance but without jobs. And the few lucky enough to have a job will become poor after paying for everyone else. That’s what happens in every commie country, as the country Obama and his comrades are trying to create in the U.S. with “help-the-poor” scams like Obamacre.

Heritage estimates the Obamacare scam will kill 690,000 jobs a year.

However, as Santorum indicates, today begins "the fight against this tyranny to reclaim our birthright."

The bill is not perfect, but will be improved over the coming years. The tragedy is that the Republicans decided to play politics with peoples' lives. For ex-Senator Santorum to claim that the bill will cause the abortion of millions of unborn children is simply not true (and the President even signed an executive order explicitly blocking the spending of federal funds on abortions). Santorum's claim that only "useful lives" will get healthcare is an astonishing distortion of the bill.

Say what you want to about the details of the bill (and yes, I have actually read the vast majority of it) but the facts are undeniable. People will get sick. They will either get medical care (which ultimately - we, the people - will pay for, either by higher premiums or higher taxes) or they will die, often with a whole lot more pain and suffering for themselves and their families than if they had gotten care earlier. This bill might well stimulate enough proactive or early care that the overall mortality rates could drop nicely.

Its time to stop pretending that the objections to this bill are anything more than politics. Either we have an obligation as human beings to reach out and help one another in times of illness or we don't. I say we do and am willing to pay my fair share. The American people would not be nearly so riled up against this bill if the Republicans had told the truth about it (I wonder how many Congressmen have actually read as much of the bill as I have). Insane exaggerations such as Mrs. Palin's claim of a "death panel" were designed to incite political turmoil. What the bill actually offered was coverage for counseling on terminal illness and how to handle it. When my time comes, I do surely want access to that kind of help on spiritual and medical issues and I want my family to have it too. The bill says absolutely nothing - and never has - about anyone choosing who gets to live and who gets to die.

"President Obama and the Democrats had something to offer. The Republicans didn’t." Pffft. Typical liberal speak. Nothing like an ignorant statement to justify your actions. THE GOP DIDN'T OFFER ANYTHING? ARE YOU SURE? Just because you liberals didn't like what the GOP offered didn't they didn't offer anything.

At last health care for ALL Americans.Is it a perfect bill, no, but it is a major step in a positive direction.
A great day for American society for ALL children and the poor who would otherwise be without will now have health care.

Alan Lyons

Is Rick Santorum a lunatic?  I'm serious.  He sounds like an individual in need of a mental health break.  His words are completely unhinged from reality, unless he believes it's the birthright of every freedom-loving patriot to not have access to health care.

Why in the world would you allow Rick Santorum to perpetuate the falsehood that "care will be rationed so only those “useful lives” will be given the care they need."  Really, NYTimes, I expect better from you.

It's nowhere near enough, but it's something, and if it can be used as the thin edge of the wedge that enables a truly public plan, then there is reason to celebrate.

As for the 212 who voted against it; they should be publicly named and shamed as often as possible between now and the next election. US citizens deserve better - both better health care and better representatives than these petty, self-interested, partisan pettifoggers.

The law can be challenged on constitutional grounds. The law can be repealed.  The balance of power in both senate and house can change.  Obama is likely a one termer.  Bush was voted out more so than Obama was voted in. The base that supports Obama's liberal policy agenda is less than 30% of voters. Opposition to a law has seldom been so animated.  The memory of this double cross of voters' wishes will be fresh come November.

The nitty-gritty of the health care plan appears to be the handing of 30 million people into the clutches of the health insurers, with large subsidies paid to the insurers to cover the insureds premiums. In return for these 30 million additional customers, the insurance companies have agreed to take all comers, to establish state insurance exchanges (in essence equivalent to the presently existing state insurance pools for drivers unable to acquire auto insurance, at much higher rates, of course) , and a few other minor concessions.

On the face of it, it just doesnt appear to to do anything toward doing away with the greedy and unnecessary middle man in health care, nor does it promote universal health care in the U.S.

The last big snow-job Congress and the Presidency pulled on the American public was the WMD farce as an excuse to invade a country we had no business to be in; before Obama's term is over, I believe we'll look on this "health-care reform" as just another snow job of gullible Americans by it's elected representatives.

Would you believe I voted for Obama?
